I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) seeks to support the Government 
of Mongolia in developing a comprehensive green finance policy and regulatory framework, and 
in undertaking capacity development to enhance the country’s environmental sustainability.1 The 
TA is included in the country operations business plan of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
2020–2021 for Mongolia.2 It is in line with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Mongolia, 2017–
2020  on  three  strategic  pillars:  (i)  promoting  economic  and  social  stability,  (ii)  developing 
infrastructure for economic diversification, and (iii) strengthening environmental sustainability.3 It 
also supports Strategy 2030’s operational priority on tackling climate change, building climate and 
disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability.4 Strategy 2030 indicates that 
climate finance from ADB’s own resources will reach $80 billion cumulatively from 2019 to 2030. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Mongolia’s  deteriorating  environmental  conditions.  Increasing  environmental 
degradation is a critical issue for Mongolia. Mongolia suffers the environmental consequences 
from urbanization and exploitation of natural resources, including air pollution, limited water 
resources and water pollution, land degradation caused by mining activities, and desertification. 
Air pollution in Mongolia’s capital city, Ulaanbaatar, is among the highest in the world.5 Raw coal 
burning by households and low pressure boilers in ger districts mainly contribute to the high air 
pollution levels. In January 2018, it was reported that Ulaanbaatar reached one of the highest 
levels of particulate matter less than 2.5 micrometers in diameter per cubic meter rate of 3,320, 
which is 133 times the recommended safety level set by the World Health Organization.6 In 
addition, total greenhouse gas emissions in Mongolia in 2014 is at 34,482.73 gigagrams of carbon 
dioxide equivalent, excluding land use, land use change, and forestry. This represented a 57.09% 
increase from the 1990 level and a 5.49% increase from the 2013 level.7 Extreme air pollution in 
Mongolia remains a constant struggle, as it gives rise to health problems and related economic 
costs, including additional health expenditures and labor productivity losses resulting from work 
absences due to illness, as well as agricultural yield losses. To mitigate the adverse effects of 
pollution and meet the demand for investment for environmental protection and sustainable 
economic development, Mongolia needs to create a supportive policy environment to enhance 
environmental sustainability. 
 
3.  Government’s policies and strategies to combat environmental challenges. The 
government recognizes the country’s sustainability issues and has approved a series of programs 
and policies to encourage green development in the country. In 2014, the National Green 
Development Policy set up the measurable targets of increasing energy efficiency by 20% by 
2030 and increasing the share of renewable energy in total energy generation to 20% by 2020 
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 October 2019. 
2  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2020–2021. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of 
Economic Difficulty. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
5  Overseas Environmental Cooperation Center. 2014. Report of the Cooperation Programme on Developing the Joint 
Crediting Mechanism Seeds in Mongolia, Feasibility Studies on Joint Crediting Mechanism Projects towards 
Environmentally Sustainable Cities in Asia. Tokyo. 
6  J. Hincks. 2018. Life in the Most Polluted Capital in the World. Time. 23 March. 
7  Government of Mongolia, Ministry of Environment and Tourism (MET). 2017. Mongolia’s Initial Biennial Update 
Report. Ulaanbaatar.

2 
and  to  30%  by  2030.  Moreover,  the  Nationally  Determined  Contributions  under  the  Paris 
Agreement 2016 focused on the energy, industry, agriculture, and waste sectors. The expected 
mitigation impact of these policies and measures will be a 14% reduction in total national 
greenhouse gas emissions, excluding land use, land use change, and forestry by 2030, compared 
with the projected emissions under a business-as-usual scenario.8 Moreover, the Government of 
Mongolia’s Sustainable Development Vision 2030 offers an ambitious set of goals centered on 
economic growth and diversification, ecological balance, and social stability.9 The country strives 
to achieve upper-middle-income status by 2030 while ending all forms of poverty; reducing 
income  inequality;  promoting  green  economy  growth;  and  building  a  stable,  professional 
governance system. 
 
4.  Mongolia’s green finance initiative. In 2015, the Bank of Mongolia (BOM) issued an 
official  directive  requiring  all  banks  to  include  the  implementation  status  of  the  Mongolian 
Sustainable Finance Principles in their annual reports starting in 2016.10 The Ministry of Finance 
(MOF) is working on the introduction of sustainable public procurement standards through the 
Amendment to the Law on Public Procurement (2018). The Ministry of Environment and Tourism 
(MET) has introduced tax exemptions for 41 types of green technologies. The MOF, the BOM, 
and the Financial Regulatory Commission of Mongolia have approved the Financial Market 
Development Program 2025, which covers strategic objectives to build a more stable financial 
system, including a dedicated section for sustainable and green finance targets. However, the 
regulations of the Financial Market Development Program 2025 lack consistent enforcement 
mechanisms.11 Mongolia still faces many challenges in achieving its ambitious sustainability goals 
and targets. 
 
5.  Inadequate national green finance policy and regulatory framework. The green 
finance development in Mongolia is still limited and lacks a comprehensive national policy and 
regulatory framework to guide and promote green investment and green finance. It also lacks a 
road map and detailed action plan for effective implementation. The challenges faced by the 
country are (i) the absence of a legal and regulatory framework directly related to green finance, 
(ii) weak institutional mechanisms for policy and administrative coordination, and (iii) insufficient 
correlation of targets of sustainable growth with priorities of national investment policy. To support 
the alignment of all stakeholders in the finance sector, green finance policies, guidelines, as well 
as legal and regulatory frameworks with interagency coordination need to be introduced and well 
designed. Moreover, the lack of clarity in green finance as to what constitutes green finance 
activities and products, such as green loans and green bonds, is an obstacle for investors, 
companies, and banks seeking to identify opportunities for green investment. 
 
6.  Limited  access  to  green  finance.  The  major  barrier  for  Mongolia  to  achieve  its 
sustainability goals and targets is the lack of green financial incentives and investments. The 
                                                
8  Government of Mongolia. 2015. Intended Nationally Determined Contribution Submission by Mongolia to the Ad-Hoc 
Working Group on the Durban Platform for Enhanced Action. Ulaanbaatar. 
9  Government of Mongolia. 2016. Sustainable Development Vision 2030. Ulaanbaatar. 
10 Mongolia’s transition toward a sustainable financial system is mostly driven by a private sector-led initiative called 
the Mongolian Sustainable Finance Initiative. As part of this initiative, the Mongolian Sustainable Finance Principles 
were launched in 2014 as the result of a joint effort from the Mongolian Bankers Association and its member banks, 
with the support of the MET and the BOM, and with international support. The principles are designed to help banks 
identify,  mitigate,  and  manage  environmental  and  social  risks.  Mongolian  Bankers  Association.  Mongolian 
Sustainable Finance Principles. 
11 United Nations Environment Programme, Inquiry Into the Design of a Sustainable Financial System; International 
Finance Corporation; and Mongolian Sustainable Finance Association. 2018. National Sustainable Finance 
Roadmap of Mongolia: Unlocking Mongolia’s Potential to Become a Sustainable Finance Knowledge Centre in the 
Region. Geneva.

3 
Mongolian financial system is dominated by banks, which represented about 88% of finance 
sector assets in 2017. The nonbank finance sector, including insurance and the stock market, is 
still small. Mongolian financial institutions lack long-term funding and a domestic deposit base. 
Moreover, lending interest rates remain high. The average annual loan interest rate was 17.7% 
for banks in 2018, and 51.6 % for nonbank financial institutions for local currency lending in 
2017.12 The Mongolian economy is heavily reliant on the mining sector, placing the country at risk 
of global price fluctuations for commodities. Almost 90% of registered businesses in Mongolia are 
small and medium-sized enterprises, and most of them have limited access to finance and are 
unable to contribute sufficiently to diversification of the economy, employment creation, and 
economic growth. New green project developers that lack track records and collateral assets face 
difficulties in meeting banks’ requirements for collateral to guarantee loans. Green financing 
contributes to a small part of the total loan portfolio of the finance sector. In the absence of a 
commonly agreed definition of green projects and assets, monitoring green financing flows has 
been limited. Based on individual banks’ own green finance definitions, the total size of green 
lending was estimated at 5% of total loan assets in 2017 (footnote 11).The financial market also 
lacks long-term financing sources and there are no substantial institutional investors, such as life 
insurance providers and pension funds. The nascent capital market needs to be diversified 
through new and innovative instruments like green bonds to diversify funding sources and to 
access low-cost capital for green infrastructure and investment. 
 
7.  Weak capacity to promote green finance. The government lacks the capacity and 
resources to implement the green finance policies effectively. It has (i) limited capacity to assess, 
identify, measure, and develop green finance projects; (ii) limited experience to implement the 
existing regulations; and (iii) no adequate human resources and experts to promote green finance 
and measure environmental impact. More generally, while legal and regulatory frameworks are 
now in place for environmental protection, their objectives far outstrip enforcement capacity. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: environmental sustainability in Mongolia 
enhanced (footnote 9). The TA will have the following outcome: comprehensive green finance 
policy and regulatory framework in Mongolia enhanced.13 The project will deliver four intended 
outputs. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  The TA will help the government to promote green finance through (i) establishing national 
strategies and guidelines, (ii) proposing a road map and action plan, (iii) proposing design of green 
financial products and innovative financing projects, and (iv) strengthening capacity development. 
The TA will organize at least four workshops for knowledge exchanges and the sharing of good 
practice examples. It will provide advisory and capacity development consulting services to the 
government. 
 
                                                
12 World Bank. Open Data. Lending Interest Rate (accessed 30 September 2019); Government of Mongolia, Financial 
Regulatory Commission. 2017. Loan Interest of Non-Bank Financial Institutions to Be Lowered. News release. 10 
January. 
13 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
10.  Output 1: National strategies and guidelines for green finance developed. This 
output will include (i) a review of the international green finance practices and an assessment of 
the existing national green finance system to determine the strategies for the government; and (ii) 
establishment of national strategies, policy recommendations, and guidelines for green finance 
with the key stakeholders, including regulators, policy makers, and financial institutions. The legal 
and regulatory frameworks will include identification of medium-term and long-term targets and 
milestones. 
 
11.  Output 2: A road map and action plan for green finance prepared. Based on the 
strategies and guidelines, the TA will provide a road map and action plan for green finance with 
practical recommendations suitable for Mongolia to address the issue of a lack of long-term 
funding, financial incentives, and investments. The TA will also prepare an overview and analysis 
of worldwide efforts on defining green finance with the means and scope for identifying green 
assets and activities through conceptual definitions, taxonomies, rating methodologies, and other 
mechanisms, based on data collected through literature review, interviews, and surveys with the 
key stakeholders and the international financial community. The action plan will support the 
implementation of the road map, including timelines, responsibilities, and expected outcomes. 
 
12.  Output 3: Green financial products and innovative financing projects to promote 
green development proposed. The TA will propose practical recommendations for investment 
strategies that are suitable with the country situation. The design of green financial products and 
innovative financing projects in line with the proposed investment strategies will be identified 
based on market assessments and good international practices. This will be done in close 
consultation with the government and in collaboration with financial institutions. A list of green 
financing projects suitable for potential funding support from ADB and other foreign financial 
institutions to promote green finance will be proposed. 
 
13.  Output 4: Capacity for green finance strengthened. The TA will prepare a capacity 
development  plan  involving  the  key  stakeholders,  including  regulators,  policy  makers,  and 
financial institutions, to develop their capacity for green finance based on international good 
practices and the TA project’s outputs 1, 2, and 3. The TA will help key stakeholders to enhance 
their knowledge on financial markets; investment instruments analysis; and capacity to assess, 
identify, measure, develop, and manage green finance products and projects. The TA will support 
at least four workshops for knowledge exchanges and the sharing of good practice examples. 
The output will also help design leaflets, brochures, and guides that can be used to promote green 
finance concepts. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). 
 
15.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, access 
to needed data and printed documents, facilities for key meetings between the implementing 
agency and consultants, printing and distribution of project materials to staff, assistance in 
coordinating meetings, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. The executing agency is the MOF. The implementing agency 
is the Financial Policy Department of the MOF. Coordination among regulators will be assured by

5 
establishing a task force comprising representatives from the MOF the MOF, Financial Regulatory 
Commission, MET, and BOM. Task force meetings will be held quarterly to review and endorse 
the proposals of the TA. The TA will require two international consultants for 5 person-months 
and four national consultants for 42 person-months. The consultants will be individually selected 
and  engaged  by  ADB  under  time-based  contracts.  The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in the table.

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and associated staff instructions.14  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for the Green Finance Policy Framework, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.
